title: The Ultimate Next.js Dashboard Stack (Shadcn, WebSocket / SSE, OLTP / OLAP Database)

rawLines.text: Hey everyone, in this video we're going
to talk about real time analytical
dashboards in Nex.js. So if you're
building an app and your app has a lot
of data that needs to be analyzed or
monitored, you probably need some kind
of dashboard and maybe you want to
continuously update basically real time.
Right now in this video, I'll show you
some of the tools that you can use, some
of the things you want to pay attention
to. But I have to say these days,
building a dashboard like this is much
easier than it used to be. There are
some new tools that make a lot of things
much easier. So in this case actually I
have an example of let's say a web
analytics dashboard. So maybe you are
monitoring the data for a particular uh
website or something like that and
there's continuously data here being
streamed into the dashboard. So let's
actually take a look and uh see how we
can build something like this. All right
so we're using nextjs in this video. Now
nextjs is a fullstack framework. So it
has both a client side as well as a
server side. And actually this
simplifies a lot of things. We don't
need a separate back end. It's just one
app essentially. Now to uh display data
and have these graphs and so on, you
probably want to use some kind of
component library. And typically they
are going to be client components
although they could also be server
components. It's not really important.
But basically for the UI itself, you
probably want to go with something like
well shad CN UI is really popular these
days. Um you've probably seen it around.
This is a bit different from other
component libraries because the code is
not abstracted away from you. You
basically copy paste the underlying code
like this directly into your own
codebase. So then you can customize it
exactly to fit your need. It's also
completely based on Tailwind actually.
So so if you're already familiar with
that, I think this is the way to go. But
there are some other options as well,
notably Tremor. Tremor is actually quite
an underrated option in my view. But
these are also some really nice
components for uh charts for any kind of
dashboard. And actually it's interesting
that they also recently joined forcell.
So chaten actually also joined forcell.
So now forcel so forcel seems to really
invest into these components for
building dashboards. Now with Tremor, if
we go to blocks and templates here, if
you take a look at some of the blocks
they have, which is basically just a
combination of those components, a more
fleshed out example essentially. They
actually also provide you with the raw
source code, you could say. Also nicely
using Tailwind. So quite similar already
to Shad Cen UI, I would say. But those
are some really modern uh options that I
think definitely deserve to get a good
look. I'm actually using Shad Cen in
this example. That's what I will use. By
the way, the reason you want to use a
component library in the first place is
because they have worked on a lot of
details that you don't have to think
about anymore. So, for example, if you
have a dialogue open like this, if I
press tab, you can see it tabs between
these buttons. So, the focus as it's
called is trapped within the model here.
If you don't trap the focus, if you
press tab, it will actually just
continue with the other things here on
the page, right? So, then it would uh
tap perhaps this input field here. And
also of course when I press escape the
dialogue should close again and the
button that you clicked should be
focused again. Right? So there's all
these little details that we don't have
to think about anymore because the
component library has already abstracted
that away. Now Shhatsen is actually
using radics under the hood and actually
a lot of the abstraction is actually
coming from radics. So is essentially
just a tillin CSS layer over radics in
my view. But that's what makes it really
good. So that's what I would use for the
UI. Now these uh components that you see
here of course they need actual data to
have something to display in the first
place. So the data will be coming from
your nextjs back end and if we want to
make a so-called realtime dashboard
right with real time I basically just
mean right continuously streaming in
data typically you want to have some
kind of connection between the client
side and server side. So we can use
something like websocket or what's
actually also underrated in my view is
server side event. Basically uh these
two options will set up a connection
between the browser and the server side
and this allows them to communicate
continuously. Now there are some slight
differences between them. They each have
their pros and cons. Typically
websockets are a little bit more
cumbersome to set up. There's a little
bit more work involved but I would say
they're a little bit more powerful. So
web with websockets you can communicate
from both server side to client side and
the client can also send back messages
to the server side. So it's birectional.
With server side events, it's a bit of
an easier setup. There are some more
limitation. So only the NextJS server
side is sending messages to the client
side, which in our case, if you're
building a dashboard like this, because
in a dashboard like this, I do not need
to send messages from the dashboard back
to the server again. It only needs to
get data from the server side. So then
it can update the UI here. It's a bit
easier to set up. So actually, that's
what I will use in the example in a
second. Your NextJS server side of
course will need some data source. Now
maybe you already have some data maybe
in your own database maybe you're
getting data from a third party and that
data may come in uh continuously so
maybe somebody else is sending you
continuously perhaps data you can choose
to put the data in a database or maybe
you immediately want to send it as a
message to the client side using one of
these protocol or maybe both you want to
put it in your in your own database and
also immediately send it to the client
side but you will need some kind of uh
data source right now typically you will
have some database and you will add data
to your database and you will also get
data read data from your database. What
I will do in this app is we will add
data to the database and then also read
data from the database. When we read
data from the database we will then
immediately send it to the client. Now
the database actually in my view is the
most important piece because as you'll
see a lot of these other things have
been made very easy. A few years ago, if
you wanted to build a dashboard like
this, this would be pretty hard and
there would be all sorts of bottlenecks
here. But honestly, a lot of the rough
edges here have been ironed out. The
biggest gains you can get essentially in
my view is by picking the right
database. Now, there are actually
different types of uh databases or ways
to store data. So, it's not just oh, I'm
just going to pick postgress, right? Or
my SQL or SQLite even. You need to be a
little bit more familiar with the
different types of queries that your app
is going to make. So if you're an app
developer, very often you are building
apps that have relatively simple
database queries. So as an example, you
may be building an app and you need to
simply create a new user in your table.
So you would do something like insert
into the users table user information,
right? Just creating one row into our
table or maybe you need to update
somebody's email. So basically you're
going to you're going to get the uh
particular row and you change the email
or just uh delete a user. And so these
are relatively simple queries and pretty
much any database system can deal with
these. Right? So this is called uh OLTP
online transactional processing. So
these are more transactional queries.
Very quick oneoff one row simple
queries. So if you're building a blog
app or an e-commerce website or a to-do
app, let's say, right? These are all
typically the only type of database
system you need is some kind of OLTP
setup. However, for an analytics
dashboard like this, you want to be a
little bit careful with that. An OLTP
database system is not optimized for a
very analytical workload. So there is
also something called OLAP, analytical
processing. A database system like that
is more optimized for an analytical type
of work and these typically involve
aggregation. So for example, we want to
see the average session duration among
all the users or we want to get all the
user interactions on a form let's say
between a particular date. Right? So now
you're not just dealing with one piece
of data essentially in your database.
You're dealing with multiple pieces of
data. So data needs to be aggregated. It
needs to be combined maybe by date. So
those types of queries can become much
more complex. So some examples would be
um if you want to do some analysis for
your e-commerce website, right? You
would maybe get from a particular
category some all the sales and then
group them by category or you want to
see some trends trends in your data.
Basically you're combining multiple
pieces of data and you're grouping it by
some way by date perhaps. And so this
can get really really complex for
workloads like that. You probably want
to use an OLAP database system. And so
you need to be aware of this. Now,
traditionally, this would be a problem
because if you're building an app,
you're probably going to have some
simple queries, right? Your your
standard transactional query, creating a
post in a database, editing a post in a
database, you pretty much always need
this. But then if you do want to add
some analytical power to your app or in
a separate app, but with the same data,
you would need to find some separate
solution. So then so then you would have
perhaps one database for your standard
queries and then you would maybe have
some other system for your analytical
workloads very cumbersome. However,
there are some solutions these days that
actually allow us to stick to one
database solution and we can use both of
these with the same system. So I'm
actually going to use duck DB in this
video. We can use duct DB in combination
with Postgress and duct DB is what
allows us to do these analytical type of
queries efficiently as well and we can
just stick to using Postgress. So we can
add duct DB to our Postgrass database
for those analytical type of queries.
It's open source. You can read all about
it here on their GitHub page. Now we
could manually add it to our Postgress
database and host it ourselves. It would
be nice if that was taken care of for us
and that's where Hydra comes into play.
They are today's sponsor and they allow
us to use Postgress with duct DB. So we
can use one database for our entire app
with that powerful analytical capability
as well. So I will use a Hydra database
in my setup here. Um so Hydra is a high
performance Postgress database with that
OLAP capability. We can use it both
locally as well as a cloud offering
which I will actually use because it
comes with a nice UI as well. So I can
inspect my data. But if we take a look

basically what we can do in Postgress of
course we create tables. So we can
create a table under the analytics
schema. So basically you have the

create a table in that nameace and that

for us for analytical queries. And then
if we want we can also have our standard

using Postgress. But now we get the

and then we're using duct DB here for
those table. You can read all about it

interesting. But let me show you how all
